unit_title: Non-Uniform Circular Motion: Variable Speed Circular Motion
subject: AP Physics C: Mechanics
expanded_description: This unit provides an in-depth analysis of non-uniform circular motion, where objects move in circular paths with changing speeds. Students will master the mathematical treatment of tangential acceleration, analyze complex scenarios like vertical circles and spiraling motion, and apply energy methods to solve problems involving variable speed circular dynamics.
learning_objectives: Analyze and calculate tangential and centripetal acceleration components
Apply Newton's Second Law to non-uniform circular motion problems
Use energy conservation to solve vertical circle problems
Solve problems involving angular acceleration and time-dependent motion
Analyze constrained non-uniform circular motion in mechanical systems
Apply calculus to solve non-uniform circular motion with variable forces
Analyze the transition between circular and other types of motion
prerequisites: Mastery of uniform circular motion concepts
Understanding of Newton's Laws and force analysis

core_concept.principle: Tangential Acceleration, Angular Acceleration, Variable Speed, Energy Methods, Constraint Forces, Transition Analysis
core_concept.explanation: Non-uniform circular motion involves both centripetal acceleration (changing direction) and tangential acceleration (changing speed). Analysis requires simultaneous consideration of radial and tangential force components, often using energy methods and calculus.

image.caption: Analysis of circular motion with variable speed and acceleration components

sections.introduction: Detailed analysis of acceleration components in non-uniform circular motion, including the mathematical relationships between tangential, centripetal, and total acceleration, and their corresponding force components.

key_concept.definition: Tangential Acceleration, Centripetal Acceleration, Total Acceleration, Force Components, Angular Acceleration
key_concept.context: In non-uniform circular motion, the total acceleration has two perpendicular components: centripetal acceleration (directed toward the center, changing velocity direction) and tangential acceleration (directed tangent to the path, changing speed).

image.caption: Analysis of acceleration components in non-uniform circular motion

classifications.value: Classification based on acceleration patterns and force characteristics
classifications.behavior: Different acceleration patterns produce specific speed profiles and force variations. Constant tangential acceleration yields linear speed change. Time-dependent acceleration requires integration. Position-dependent acceleration often allows energy methods. Each scenario requires appropriate mathematical treatment.

examples.explanation: Systematic approach for resolving forces and accelerations into radial and tangential components

image.caption: Resolution of forces into radial and tangential components

examples.explanation: Geometric and mathematical analysis of acceleration vector relationships

classifications.note: Key relationships: a_radial = v²/r, a_tangential = dv/dt = rα, a_total = √(a_radial² + a_tangential²), θ = arctan(a_tangential/a_radial)

principles.statement: Non-uniform circular motion requires analysis of both acceleration components: Acceleration Components: Radial (centripetal): a_r = v²/r, always toward center; Tangential: a_t = dv/dt = rα, tangent to path; Total: a = √(a_r² + a_t²). Force Components: Radial: ΣF_r = mv²/r provides centripetal acceleration; Tangential: ΣF_t = mdv/dt changes speed; These are perpendicular and independent. Angular Relationships: Angular acceleration: α = dω/dt = a_t/r; For constant α: ω = ω₀ + αt, θ = θ₀ + ω₀t + ½αt². Vector Nature: Acceleration vector points inside the circle, not toward center; Angle from radial: φ = arctan(a_t/a_r). Speed Variations: Linear speed change: v = v₀ + a_tt for constant a_t; Position-dependent: use energy methods. Problem-Solving Strategy: 1. Identify all forces; 2. Resolve into radial and tangential components; 3. Apply ΣF_r = mv²/r; 4. Apply ΣF_t = mdv/dt; 5. Use kinematic relationships; 6. Solve system of equations. Special Cases: Pure tangential force: circular path with changing speed; Pure radial force: uniform circular motion; Mixed forces: general non-uniform motion.
principles.application: Calculate acceleration components in various scenarios. Analyze force components in non-uniform motion. Solve problems with angular acceleration. Determine speed variations with position. Apply vector analysis to acceleration. Solve time-dependent circular motion. Analyze transitional motion.
principles.example: Car accelerating on circular track. Object on string with changing pull. Vertical circular motion. Particle in magnetic field. Roller coaster with acceleration. Spinning up flywheel.
principles.analogy: Non-uniform circular motion is like driving a car on a circular track while pressing the accelerator or brake - you feel both the sideways push toward the center (keeping you on track) and the forward/backward push (changing your speed), and both sensations combine to tell you your total acceleration

worked_examples.title: Car Accelerating on Circular Track
worked_examples.problem: A 1200 kg car moves on a 50 m radius circular track. Its speed increases from 10 m/s to 20 m/s uniformly over 5 seconds. Find: (a) tangential acceleration, (b) centripetal acceleration at start and end, (c) total acceleration at t=2.5 s, (d) net force magnitude and direction at t=2.5 s.

step_by_step.explanation: θ = arctan(a_t/a_r) = arctan(2/4.5) = arctan(0.444) = 24.0° from radial direction toward motion
F_net = ma_total = 1200×4.92 = 5904 N
F_r = ma_r = 1200×4.5 = 5400 N (radial inward); F_t = ma_t = 1200×2 = 2400 N (tangential)
a_r initial = 10²/50 = 2 m/s²; a_r final = 20²/50 = 8 m/s²

worked_examples.final_answer: a_t=2 m/s²; a_r at t=2.5s=4.5 m/s²; a_total=4.92 m/s² at 24.0° from radial; F_net=5904 N at 24.0° from radial

worked_examples.title: Object with Angular Acceleration
worked_examples.problem: A 0.5 kg object on 1.2 m string accelerates from rest with constant angular acceleration α=3 rad/s². Find after 2 seconds: (a) angular speed, (b) linear speed, (c) centripetal force, (d) tangential force, (e) angle swept.

step_by_step.explanation: ω = ω₀ + αt = 0 + 3×2 = 6 rad/s
φ = arctan(F_t/F_r) = arctan(1.8/21.6) = arctan(0.0833) = 4.76° from radial

worked_examples.final_answer: ω=6 rad/s, v=7.2 m/s, F_r=21.6 N, F_t=1.8 N, F_total=21.67 N at 4.76° from radial, θ=6 rad

sections.section_title: 2. Energy Methods in Vertical Circular Motion
sections.introduction: Application of energy conservation principles to analyze vertical circular motion, where gravitational potential energy changes cause speed variations, and determination of critical conditions for maintaining circular motion.

key_concept.definition: Energy Conservation, Vertical Circles, Critical Speed, Potential Energy, Work-Energy Theorem, Constraint Conditions
key_concept.context: In vertical circular motion, mechanical energy conservation relates speed variations to height changes. Critical analysis determines minimum speeds required to maintain circular motion and conditions where constraints become slack.

image.caption: Energy analysis and critical conditions in vertical circular motion

classifications.value: Classification based on constraint types and energy considerations
classifications.behavior: Different constraint types exhibit specific failure modes. Strings go slack when tension reaches zero. Tracks lose contact when normal force reaches zero. Each scenario has characteristic critical speeds and energy relationships that determine motion stability.

examples.explanation: Applying mechanical energy conservation to vertical circular motion

image.caption: Application of energy conservation to vertical circles

examples.explanation: Determining minimum speeds and forces for maintained circular motion

image.caption: Analysis of critical conditions in vertical circular motion

classifications.note: Key conditions: Top of circle: minimum v = √(rg) for contact; Bottom has maximum speed and tension; Energy: ½mv² + mgh = constant

principles.principle: Energy Methods in Vertical Circular Motion
principles.statement: Vertical circular motion analysis combines energy conservation with force analysis: Energy Conservation: ½mv² + mgh = constant; Speed-height relationship: v² = v_ref² - 2gΔh. Critical Speeds: At top: minimum v_top = √(rg) for circular motion; Required bottom speed: v_bottom = √(v_top² + 4gr) = √(5gr). Force Analysis: General tension: T = mv²/r + mg cosθ (varies with position); At bottom (θ=180°): T_max = mv²/r + mg; At top (θ=0°): T_min = mv²/r - mg. Constraint Conditions: String: circular motion maintained if T ≥ 0; Track: circular motion if N ≥ 0; Transition to projectile motion when constraint fails. Work-Energy Theorem: If non-conservative forces: W_nc = ΔKE + ΔPE; Useful for problems with friction. Problem-Solving Approach: 1. Apply energy conservation for speeds; 2. Use force analysis for tensions/normal forces; 3. Check constraint conditions; 4. Analyze transitions; 5. Verify energy consistency. Special Cases: Conical pendulum: different energy relationships; Roller coasters: track design considerations; Multiple objects: coupled energy systems.
principles.application: Solve vertical circle problems with energy methods. Determine critical speeds for circular motion. Calculate tension variations. Analyze constraint failure conditions. Solve problems with non-conservative forces. Handle multiple object systems. Analyze transitions to projectile motion.
principles.example: Ball on string in vertical circle. Roller coaster loop design. Water bucket vertical swing. Pendulum with initial impulse. Object on vertical track. Carnival ride analysis.
principles.analogy: Vertical circular motion is like a roller coaster - your speed naturally changes with height due to gravity, and there's a minimum speed needed at the top to avoid falling off the tracks, just as there's a minimum speed needed to maintain circular motion against gravity

image.caption: Principles of vertical circular motion analysis

worked_examples.title: Complete Vertical Circle Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A 2 kg mass on 1.8 m string is given just enough speed at bottom to complete vertical circle. Find: (a) minimum bottom speed, (b) speeds at 45°, 90°, 135°, (c) tensions at these positions, (d) total acceleration at 90°.

step_by_step.step: Minimum bottom speed for complete circle

step_by_step.explanation: T = mv²/r - mg = 2×17.64/1.8 - 19.6 = 19.6 - 19.6 = 0 N (just barely maintains contact)
a_r = v²/r = 52.92/1.8 = 29.4 m/s²; a_t = g (only tangential force is gravity component) = 9.8 m/s²; a_total = √(29.4² + 9.8²) = √(864.36 + 96.04) = √960.4 = 30.99 m/s²

worked_examples.final_answer: Minimum v_bottom=9.39 m/s; Speeds: 45°=8.82 m/s, 90°=7.27 m/s, 135°=5.29 m/s; Tensions: bottom=117.6 N, 45°=100.4 N, 90°=58.8 N, 135°=17.2 N, top=0 N; a_total at 90°=31.0 m/s²
worked_examples.concept_applied: Complete vertical circle analysis with energy methods

image.caption: Comprehensive analysis of vertical circular motion

worked_examples.title: Roller Coaster Loop Design
worked_examples.problem: A roller coaster car must complete a 8 m radius vertical loop. If friction and drag are negligible, find: (a) minimum height above bottom to start, (b) speed and normal force at bottom if released from this height, (c) speed and normal force at 60° from bottom.

step_by_step.explanation: At top: v_top = √(gr) = √(9.8×8) = √78.4 = 8.85 m/s; Energy: mgh_min = ½mv_top² + mg(2r) → h_min = v_top²/(2g) + 2r = 78.4/19.6 + 16 = 4 + 16 = 20 m above bottom

step_by_step.step: Speed at bottom from minimum height

step_by_step.explanation: N_bottom = mv²/r + mg = m(v²/r + g); For m=1 kg: N = (392/8 + 9.8) = 49 + 9.8 = 58.8 N (6g equivalent)
h = r(1 - cos60°) = 8(1-0.5) = 4 m above bottom
Real roller coasters use higher starting heights for safety margin
Bottom: 6g upward force; 60° position: 4.5g force directed 60° from vertical

worked_examples.final_answer: Minimum height=20 m; At bottom: v=19.8 m/s, N=58.8 N (6g); At 60°: v=17.7 m/s, N=44.1 N (4.5g)

sections.introduction: Analysis of complex non-uniform circular motion scenarios involving mechanical constraints, variable radii, coupled systems, and transitions between circular and other types of motion.

key_concept.definition: Constrained Motion, Variable Radius, Coupled Systems, Mechanical Links, Transition Analysis, Complex Constraints
key_concept.context: Advanced non-uniform circular motion involves systems with mechanical constraints that couple circular motion with other types of motion, variable radii that change during motion, and transitions between different motion regimes.

image.caption: Analysis of complex constrained non-uniform circular motion

classifications.value: Classification based on constraint types and system complexity
classifications.behavior: Different constrained systems exhibit specific coupling behaviors. Variable radius systems involve changing centripetal requirements. Mechanical linkages transfer motion between components. Coupled systems have energy exchange between parts. Each scenario requires analyzing constraints and their mathematical implications.

examples.explanation: Deriving mathematical relationships from physical constraints in complex systems

image.caption: Development of constraint equations for complex systems

examples.explanation: Analyzing behavior during transitions between motion regimes

image.caption: Analysis of transitions between motion types

classifications.note: Key approaches: Identify all constraints; Use Lagrange multipliers for complex constraints; Analyze energy exchange in coupled systems; Monitor constraint forces during transitions

principles.statement: Complex non-uniform circular motion requires extended analysis methods: Variable Radius Motion: Spiral motion: r(t) changes; Centripetal acceleration: a_r = v²/r(t); Complex speed relationships; Conservation of angular momentum often applies. Mechanical Linkages: Constrained by geometry; Multiple connected bodies; Coupled equations of motion; Often require numerical solution. Coupled Pendulum Systems: Energy exchange between pendulums; Complex oscillation patterns; Coupled differential equations. Rotating Platform Problems: Objects on rotating surfaces; Friction constraints; Critical speeds for slipping; Combined inertial and rotating frame analysis. Sliding Constraints: Objects on curved tracks; Normal force variations; Transition to free motion when constraints fail. Multi-Body Systems: Several interconnected objects; Multiple constraint equations; Matrix methods for solution. Transition Analysis: Circular to projectile motion; Circular to linear motion; Critical transition conditions; Energy and momentum conservation. Problem-Solving Strategy: 1. Identify all constraints and degrees of freedom; 2. Write constraint equations; 3. Apply Newton's Laws with constraints; 4. Use energy and momentum methods; 5. Solve system of equations; 6. Analyze transitions and critical points. Advanced Techniques: Lagrangian mechanics for complex constraints; Numerical integration for non-analytic solutions; Phase space analysis for oscillatory systems.
principles.application: Analyze variable radius circular motion. Solve mechanical linkage problems. Handle coupled pendulum systems. Analyze objects on rotating platforms. Solve sliding constraint problems. Work with multi-body systems. Analyze motion transitions. Apply advanced solution methods.
principles.example: Particle spiraling in magnetic field. Four-bar linkage dynamics. Coupled pendulum motion. Object on rotating turntable. Bead on rotating wire. Multiple masses on strings. Ball rolling off circular track.
principles.analogy: Constrained non-uniform circular motion is like a complex dance where the dancers' movements are interconnected by the music (constraints) - each dancer follows their own path, but their motions are coupled, and sometimes they transition between different dance styles (motion regimes) while maintaining the rhythm of the constraints

worked_examples.title: Bead on Rotating Wire
worked_examples.problem: A bead slides without friction on a wire rotating with constant angular velocity ω=4 rad/s. The bead is released at r=0.2 m with zero radial velocity. Find: (a) radial acceleration, (b) tangential acceleration, (c) constraint force, (d) motion equation and solution.

step_by_step.explanation: Use polar coordinates (r,θ) with θ = ωt
In rotating frame: a_r = d²r/dt² - rω²
a_θ = 2ω(dr/dt) + r(dω/dt) = 2ω(dr/dt) (since dω/dt=0)
Only radial constraint force F_r; No tangential force (frictionless)
F_r = m(d²r/dt² - rω²); But F_r provides centripetal component
In inertial frame, bead has both radial and tangential motion
v_r = dr/dt; v_θ = rω; Total v² = (dr/dt)² + r²ω²
No potential energy change; Kinetic energy constant if no friction

step_by_step.step: Wait - constraint force does work in rotating frame
step_by_step.explanation: Better to solve in inertial frame using polar coordinates
a_r = d²r/dt² - r(dθ/dt)² = d²r/dt² - rω²; a_θ = r d²θ/dt² + 2(dr/dt)(dθ/dt) = 2ω(dr/dt)
Radial: -F_r = m(d²r/dt² - rω²); Tangential: 0 = m(2ω dr/dt) → contradiction unless dr/dt=0
The wire exerts both radial and tangential constraint forces; Tangential force needed to maintain θ=ωt
Radial: -F_r = m(d²r/dt² - rω²); Tangential: F_θ = 2mω(dr/dt)
d²r/dt² - ω²r = 0 → r(t) = A e^(ωt) + B e^(-ωt); With IC: r(t) = 0.2 cosh(ωt)
Bead moves outward exponentially; Demonstrates centrifugal effect

worked_examples.final_answer: Radial motion: r(t)=0.2 cosh(4t) m; Bead accelerates outward due to centrifugal effect in rotating frame

image.caption: Analysis of bead motion on rotating wire

worked_examples.title: Transition from Circular to Projectile Motion
worked_examples.problem: A 0.5 kg ball on 1.2 m string is swinging in vertical circle. When string makes 30° with vertical, its speed is 6 m/s and string breaks. Describe subsequent motion and find: (a) position and velocity when break occurs, (b) maximum height reached, (c) range from break point.

step_by_step.explanation: String at 30° with vertical; Height above bottom: h = r(1 - cos30°) = 1.2(1-0.866) = 0.161 m
Tangential to circle: v_tang = 6 m/s; Radial: v_rad = 0 (circular motion)
At 30° from vertical: x-component: v_x = 6 cos30° = 5.196 m/s; y-component: v_y = 6 sin30° = 3 m/s (upward)
x = r sin30° = 1.2×0.5 = 0.6 m; y = r cos30° = 1.2×0.866 = 1.039 m (height above center)
Assume center at height 1.2 m: h_max = 1.2 + 1.039 + 0.459 = 2.698 m
Time up + time down from h_max; Time down: t_down = √(2h_max/g) = √(2×2.698/9.8) = √0.5506 = 0.742 s; Total t = 0.306 + 0.742 = 1.048 s
Range = v_x × t_total = 5.196 × 1.048 = 5.445 m from break point
Ball lands 5.445 m horizontally from break position
Parabolic path beginning tangent to circular path at break point

worked_examples.final_answer: Break at: x=0.6 m, y=1.039 m (from center), v_x=5.20 m/s, v_y=3.00 m/s; Maximum height=2.70 m; Range=5.45 m from break point

common_misconceptions: Thinking circular motion always has constant speed
Believing centripetal force is a separate type of force
Thinking objects in vertical circles have constant tension
Believing centrifugal force causes outward motion in inertial frames
Confusing angular and linear acceleration relationships
Thinking energy conservation doesn't apply to circular motion
Believing constraints can provide unlimited forces
real_world_applications: Amusement park ride design and safety analysis
Automotive handling on curved roads with acceleration
Athletic performance in sports like hammer throw
Roller coaster and theme ride design
summary: Non-uniform circular motion extends basic circular dynamics to scenarios where speed changes during motion, requiring analysis of both centripetal and tangential acceleration components. Energy methods provide powerful tools for analyzing vertical circular motion and determining critical conditions for maintained circular motion. Complex constrained systems involve mechanical linkages, variable radii, and transitions between different motion regimes. These advanced concepts find application across engineering design, sports science, amusement ride safety, and mechanical system analysis, demonstrating the richness and practical importance of non-uniform circular motion in understanding and designing systems where objects follow curved paths with changing speeds.
